rich_text_content.text: As part of your Disabled Students' Allowance (DSA) award you may be provided with a new PC or laptop to run assistive software for you. If you live in England and are awarded a new PC or laptop through DSA, you'll need to contribute £200 towards the cost of that PC or laptop. You can apply for help with this cost through Funding for computers, internet and childcare etc.

You'll need to provide a copy of your DSA award letter from Student Finance England. Any award made will be paid directly to you. You'll then need to contact your equipment supplier to arrange payment and delivery of your equipment.
Funding for study-related costs may also be available for students who are not eligible for DSA but who need support towards the cost of a standard computer, laptop or tablet.

rich_text_content.text: Gallwch gael Benthyciad Ffioedd Dysgu Rhan-amser hyd yn oed os ydych yn bwriadu astudio 120 o gredydau y flwyddyn, sy'n cyfateb i ddwyster llawn amser. heading.text: Benthyciadau Ffioedd Dysgu Rhan-amser yn gryno

rich_text_content.text: Bydd angen i chi ailgyflwyno cais bob blwyddyn.
Gallwch dalu eich ffioedd yn llawn neu'n rhannol gyda benthyciad ffioedd gwerth hyd at £2,625 yn 2023/2024.
Nid yw Benthyciadau Ffioedd Dysgu Rhan-amser yn seiliedig ar brawf modd.

Byddwch yn gwneud cais am eich Benthyciad Ffioedd Dysgu Rhan-amser gan Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru. Byddwn yn eich tywys drwy'r broses, ond Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru fydd yn gwneud y penderfyniad terfynol ynglŷn â’ch cymhwysedd i gael benthyciad ffioedd.
Os ydych eisoes wedi dechrau eich modiwl gallwch wneud cais hyd at naw mis ar ôl dechrau eich blwyddyn academaidd dymhorol.
Mae ad-daliadau’n seiliedig ar yr hyn rydych yn ei ennill, nid yr hyn sy’n ddyledus gennych, a chânt eu didynnu’n awtomatig gan eich cyflogwr drwy system dreth y DU.

Byddwch yn dechrau ad-dalu eich Benthyciad Ffioedd Dysgu Rhan-amser o'r mis Ebrill bedair blynedd ar ôl i chi ddechrau eich cymhwyster neu'r mis Ebrill ar ôl i chi adael y cwrs, pa un bynnag fydd gyntaf.

Os bydd eich incwm yn disgyn islaw’r trothwy ad-dalu sy’n berthnasol i chi, bydd eich ad-daliadau’n dod i ben – er enghraifft, os byddwch yn cymryd seibiant gyrfa neu’n ddi-waith – nes bod eich enillion yn fwy na’r trothwy eto.

Bydd y meini prawf ad-dalu benthyciad sy’n berthnasol i chi yn dibynnu ar y telerau ac amodau ar gyfer y flwyddyn academaidd y dechreuodd eich benthyciad. Ewch i wefan y Cwmni Benthyciadau Myfyrwyr am ragor o fanylion.
Bydd angen i chi:
fod yn astudio modiwl sy'n werth o leiaf 30 credyd (dwyster o 25%) ym mhob blwyddyn academaidd.
bod yn astudio ar gyfer un o gymwysterau cymwys Y Brifysgol Agored i israddedigion sy'n uwch nag unrhyw gymhwyster sydd gennych ar hyn o bryd (mae rhai eithriadau i hyn*)
sicrhau nad ydych ar ei hôl hi gyda'ch ad-daliadau, mewn ôl-ddyledion, nac yn gordalu gydag unrhyw gymorth ariannol blaenorol a gawsoch gan y Cwmni Benthyciadau i Fyfyrwyr.
cwrdd â'r meini prawf preswyo sy'n ystyried eich cenedligrwydd a'ch statws preswyl. Am restr o'r categorïau cymwys, gweler Cyllid myfyrwyr: Cymhwysedd.

*Os byddwch yn astudio un o'r pynciau canlynol, efallai y byddwch yn gymwys i gael Benthyciadau Ffioedd Dysgu Rhan-amser, hyd yn oed os oes gennych eisoes radd: peirianneg, technoleg, cyfrifiadureg, nyrsio, gwyddorau biolegol, seicoleg, gwyddorau ffisegol, gwyddorau mathemateg.
Ceir rhagor o wybodaeth ar wefan Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru.
Os caiff eich cais am fenthyciad ei wrthod, neu os byddwch am newid eich dull o dalu
Bydd angen i chi gysylltu â'r adran Recriwtio Myfyrwyr ar +44 (0)300 303 5303 cyn gynted â phosibl. Gallwn drafod ffyrdd amgen o dalu ac egluro'r camau nesaf y mae angen i chi eu cymryd.

Y ffordd gyflymaf a hawsaf yw drwy ddefnyddio porth ar-lein Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru. P'un a fyddwch yn gwneud cais ar-lein neu ar bapur, mae'n bwysig sicrhau bod gennych y wybodaeth gywir wrth law. Bydd angen i Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru gael gwybodaeth benodol am eich cwrs, yn cynnwys enw'r cwrs, dyddiad dechrau'r cwrs a swm y ffioedd dysgu. Bydd angen rhoi'r wybodaeth hon iddynt mewn fformat penodol – pan fyddwch wedi cadw eich lle ar eich modiwl, ac wedi dweud wrthym eich bod yn bwriadu talu gan ddefnyddio Benthyciad Ffioedd Dysgu Rhan Amser, byddwn yn rhoi'r wybodaeth sydd ei hangen arnoch ar y dudalen 'Your student loan' ar StudentHome. Gall peidio â defnyddio'r wybodaeth hon olygu y caiff eich cais am fenthyciad ei oedi ac na chaiff eich ffioedd dysgu eu talu.
Os na allwch ddefnyddio'r gwasanaeth gwneud cais ar-lein, gallwch lawrlwytho cais papur a nodiadau canllaw neu ofyn i gopi caled gael ei anfon drwy gysylltu â Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru.

Gall y rhan fwyaf o fyfyrwyr gwblhau eu cais cyfan ar-lein. Byddwch yn gallu cytuno i'r Telerau ac Amodau drwy eich cyfrif Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru ar-lein gan ddefnyddio Llofnod Electronig. Nid oes angen i chi argraffu na llofnodi datganiad benthyciad mwyach.
Bydd Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru yn anfon llythyr Hawl i Gyllid Myfyrwyr atoch i gadarnhau bod eich benthyciad Ffioedd Dysgu Rhan-amser wedi cael ei gymeradwyo.
Mae cyfarwyddiadau manwl ar gwblhau cais llwyddiannus i'w gweld yn Benthyciadau Ffioedd Dysgu Rhan Amser - canllawiau ar gwblhau eich cais.
Os mai hwn yw eich cais cyntaf

Pan fyddwch yn creu cyfrif gyda Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru gan ddefnyddio eu porth ar-lein, byddwch yn cael Rhif Cyfeirnod Cwsmer unigryw. Unwaith y byddwch wedi cwblhau eich cais am fenthyciad ac wedi'i gyflwyno, gallwch ddefnyddio eich Rhif Cyfeirnod Cwsmer i gwblhau eich cofrestriad ar eich modiwlau dewisol.
Os byddwch yn gwneud cais gan ddefnyddio'r ffurflen gais bapur, byddwch yn cael eich Rhif Cyfeirnod Cwsmer tua 10 diwrnod gwaith ar ôl cyflwyno eich cais i Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru.
Swm eich Benthyciad Ffioedd Dysgu Rhan Amser

Dylech wneud cais am y benthyciad uchaf sydd ar gael fel na fydd yn rhaid i chi wneud cais am fenthyciad arall os byddwch yn penderfynu astudio modiwlau ychwanegol yn yr un flwyddyn academaidd dymhorol.

Dim ond swm y benthyciad sy'n ofynnol ar gyfer y modiwlau y byddwch yn eu hastudio mewn gwirionedd y bydd Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru yn eu talu. Caiff unrhyw fenthyciad heb ei ddefnyddio ar ddiwedd y flwyddyn ei ddiystyru a dim ond y rhandaliadau a dalwyd i ni mewn gwirionedd gan Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru y bydd angen i chi eu talu.
Ni allwch drosglwyddo unrhyw fenthyciad heb ei ddefnyddio a bydd angen i chi wneud cais newydd am fenthyciad ym mhob blwyddyn academaidd dymhorol.
Os byddwch yn penderfynu newid eich dull o dalu neu os yw eich modiwl wedi dechrau eisoes

Os byddwch wedi talu am eich modiwl gan ddefnyddio dull arall o dalu, ac yna'n penderfynu eich bod am newid eich taliad i fenthyciad, gallwch wneud cais am Fenthyciad Ffioedd Dysgu Rhan Amser hyd at naw mis ar ôl dechrau eich blwyddyn academaidd dymhorol berthnasol.

Os byddwch yn gwneud cais ar ôl dyddiad dechrau'r modiwl, dylech wneud cais am eich benthyciad yn y ffordd arferol (a ddangosir uchod) a chysylltu â'r adran Ffioedd Myfyrwyr pan gaiff eich benthyciad ei gymeradwyo. Unwaith y byddwn wedi cael cadarnhad gan Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru bod eich benthyciad wedi'i gymeradwyo, byddwn yn ad-dalu unrhyw ffioedd a dalwyd hyd at werth y benthyciad.
Os ydych wedi astudio mewn sefydliad addysg uwch yn flaenorol

Os ydych wedi gwneud cais am Fenthyciad Ffioedd Dysgu neu Grant Ffioedd neu Grant Cwrs ar gyfer cwrs mewn sefydliad addysg uwch arall, bydd angen i chi ddweud wrth eich prifysgol neu goleg blaenorol eich bod bellach yn astudio gyda'r Brifysgol Agored. Bydd angen iddynt roi caniatâd i Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru drosglwyddo perchenogaeth eich cyllid myfyrwyr i'r Brifysgol Agored. Os na fyddwch yn gwneud hyn, caiff eich cais am fenthyciad ei oedi. Bydd angen i chi gysylltu â'ch prifysgol neu goleg, ac nid â Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru.

Os bydd angen gwybodaeth arnoch am eich ffioedd modiwl i'ch helpu i gwblhau eich cais am fenthyciad, mae ar gael ar y dudalen 'Your student loan' yn StudentHome.
Os bydd angen help arnoch i gwblhau unrhyw agwedd arall ar eich cais, dylech gysylltu â Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru.

Os byddwch yn cael trafferth wrth ddatrys unrhyw broblemau o ran prosesau eich cais gyda Cyllid Myfyrwyr Cymru, efallai y gallwn helpu. Cysylltwch â'r adran Ffioedd Myfyrwyr a gallwn drafod y ffordd orau o ddatrys y broblem gyda chi. primary.introduction_text: If you're studying towards an undergraduate qualification with us on a part-time basis you may be eligible for a Part-time Fee Grant or Part-time Tuition Fee Loan (student loan) to help with the cost of your studies.

rich_text_content.text: All applications for financial support are processed by Student Finance Northern Ireland (SFNI) using one application form.
If you haven't already done so, choose the modules you want to study this year and tell us you’ll be applying for a loan/grant when you go through the online enrolment process.
You can apply for a Part-time Fee Grant each seasonal academic year for any qualifying modules you study until you’ve reached the maximum award.
The grant is means tested and can be used to pay all or some of your module fees if you're studying towards a qualification.
If you’re studying 30 or 60 credits a year the maximum fee grant is £820. It could be worth as much as £1,230 if you’re studying modules totalling 90 or 120 credits a year.
The grant is non-repayable.
The Part-time Fee Grant may not cover your module fees in full. If this is the case, you’ll be expected to cover any shortfall yourself or with a Part-time Tuition Fee Loan.
The amount of grant you'll receive will depend on your total household income and how many credits you’ll be studying with us.
A full award is made if your household income is below £16,843 or if you’re receiving a qualifying benefit. You may still receive some support if you have a household income of up to £25,420.
If your seasonal academic year started less than nine months ago, you may still be able to apply.
The grant is paid directly to The Open University.
If you're not eligible for a Part-time Fee Grant or your grant doesn't cover the full cost of your tuition fees, you can apply for a Part-Time Tuition Fee Loan. In brief:
Tuition Fee Loans are available for undergraduate qualifications that are at a higher level than any qualifications you have already.
Loans are not means tested; you'll be eligible to apply regardless of your income.
There is no upper age limit.
SFNI pays your module fees directly to the University and you pay them back later in monthly instalments once your income reaches the threshold.
Repayments are taken directly from your pay.
You don’t start repaying for up to four years.
Interest is charged on the loan.
If your income falls below the threshold your repayments stop – for example, if you take a career break or are unemployed – until your earnings exceed the threshold again.

The loan repayment criteria relevant to you will be dependent on the terms and conditions in place for the seasonal academic year in which your loan started. Visit the Student Loans Company website for further details.

Once you’ve registered for a qualification and reserved a module, tell us you want to pay your fees with a Part-Time Tuition Fee Loan. We'll give you the information you need on 'Your student loan' page on StudentHome to help make your application to SFNI.
When you apply for a Part-time Fee Grant you'll be automatically assessed to see if you’re also eligible for a Course Grant.
Course Grants:
Are means-tested, based on household income, or benefits entitlements.
Could help pay for study-related items such as books, stationery or travel.
Could be worth as much as £265, depending on your household income (see table below).
Are non-repayable.
In addition:
You must be studying at least 60 credits (50% study intensity).
If your seasonal academic year started less than nine months ago you might still be able to apply for support.
You can only receive one Course Grant per seasonal academic year. If you're eligible for a Course Grant you should expect to receive payment within four weeks of your module start date.

heading.text: How to apply for grants and loans

rich_text_content.text: All applications for support, including Part-time Tuition Fee Loans, are processed by SFNI using one application form.

If you're applying for support for the first time, set up an account with Student Finance Northern Ireland (SFNI). You'll need your National Insurance number. Make a note of the Customer Reference Number (CRN) as you'll need this later. If you've applied to SFNI before you won't need to set up an account, you can use your previous login details. You'll also need to note your CRN as you'll need this to complete your registration with us.
Follow the steps below to apply.
Complete the online application form.
Complete your module enrolment in StudentHome - your registration isn't complete until you've provided your CRN. You'll find your CRN when you log in to your SFNI account.
You'll need to download and/or print the Course Intensity Confirmation Form and email it to northern-ireland@open.ac.uk.
You'll also need to submit your income evidence to SFNI as soon as you've completed the online application. SFNI are not able to process your application without this evidence.
SFNI will assess your application and send a Student Finance Entitlement Letter with details of what you're entitled to once they've received all your evidence.

Contact us by phone on +44 (0)28 9032 3722 (Mon to Fri 08:30 - 17:00) or by email at northern-ireland@open.ac.uk if you have any questions or as soon as possible if your loan application has been delayed, declined or withdrawn as we can help by discussing your options. Alternatively you can also call 0300 303 5303 (Mon to Fri 08:00 - 17:30).

primary.introduction_text: For academic year 2023/24, the Open University (OU) will provide twenty UK-based carers with the opportunity to study for free with a Carers' Scholarship.  The scholarship is a full fee waiver scheme offering eligible applicants the chance to study an undergraduate OU course of their choice.

rich_text_content.text: If you currently provide or have recently provided unpaid care (with the exception of Carer’s Allowance) to someone such as a family member, partner or friend who needs help because of their illness, frailty, disability, a mental health problem or an addiction and can't cope without your support, you may be eligible to apply.

There is a maximum of twenty awards available. To encourage young adult carers to apply, six places have been reserved for those aged 25 and under. To ensure funds are allocated fairly, eligible applicants will be reviewed by a panel who will make an assessment based upon the impact of each applicant's caring responsibilities.

The fund is open to all undergraduate modules that start in the 2023/24 academic year (1 September 2023 to 31 August 2024) – applications must be received by the deadline of 21 June 2023, regardless of your chosen start date.
Eligibility
To be eligible for the fund you must:
be starting OU study for the first time (previous uncompleted OU study is not permitted)
study a module in academic year 2023/2024 (1 September 2023 to 31 August 2024)
be resident in England, Northern Ireland, Scotland or Wales and eligible to pay UK OU fees
intend to study towards an OU undergraduate qualification or module
study at least 30 credits per year
be a carer, or have previously been a carer within the last two years where the person you cared for has passed away
be, or were, completing a minimum of 15 hours per week of caring responsibilities
have a gross household income of not more than £25,000 per year or be in receipt of a qualifying benefit.
The full eligibility criteria are available in the Terms and Conditions (PDF 147 KB).
How to apply
Applications for the 2023/24 academic year are open until 21 June 2023. Before completing the application form, ensure you have read the full Terms and Conditions.

primary.introduction_text: Postgraduate students who start eligible masters qualifications from 1 August 2019 onwards are able to apply for funding, made up of grants and loans.

rich_text_content.text: The funding available depends on the academic year you started your qualification. It's paid over the duration of the masters qualification, including up to £6,885 of non-repayable grants.
Eligibility
To be eligible for postgraduate funding you must:
be studying a full masters degree of a minimum of 180 credits* - you won't be eligible if you're studying towards a postgraduate certificate or diploma
be ordinarily resident in Wales
be aged under 60 on the first day of the seasonal academic year in which your masters degree begins
be studying towards a masters degree that can be completed in no more than three years
not already hold a masters degree or higher qualification.

*If you're considering transferring previously completed credit to your OU masters degree, this could have an impact on your postgraduate loan eligibility. Contact Student Recruitment for further information.
How much will I get?
All eligible students will receive a non-means tested, non-repayable grant of £1,000.
You can then apply for a further means-tested non-repayable grant of up to £5,885, the amount you're awarded depends on your household income.

A non-means tested repayable maintenance loan is available for the remaining amount up to £18,770 for those starting in 2023/24, which is the maximum possible funding you could be awarded. This means that, regardless of your household income, you're able to access a minimum of £1,000 of non-repayable grant and the remainder as a repayable maintenance loan.

For example, if you start your studies in 2023/24, have a household income of £18,370 or below, you'll receive a total of £6,885 in non-repayable grant and up to £11,885 of maintenance loan. If your household income was £40,000, you would receive £3,767 in non-repayable grant and up to £15,003 in maintenance loan.

rich_text_content.text: How it works

The loan is paid directly to you in three instalments each year and you'll receive the first instalment after your qualification start date, not before. The loan is a contribution towards the cost of your postgraduate study and isn't considered a Tuition Fee Loan. Therefore, in order to secure your module registration you’ll need to pay your module fees, upfront yourself - for example, through an Open University Student Budget Account, by credit/debit card, or by mixed payments by the specified final enrolment date for your module. The loan will then be paid to you after you start studying, subject to meeting the eligibility criteria.
When will I receive my funding?

You will receive your funding across either two or three years of your study, the total funding will be divided by the number of years you're completing your studies in. Each year’s allocation will be paid in three instalments directly into your bank account.

Once your loan application is approved, your first module has started and you're actively studying the University will confirm your registration to Student Finance Wales (SFW) and you'll receive your first instalment.
How to apply
You should apply as soon as possible at Student Finance Wales. Applications are straightforward; be sure to select part-time as all OU masters qualifications are part-time.
To apply you'll need:
a valid UK Passport (if you have one)
your National Insurance number
your bank account details.
You'll only need to apply for your loan once to ensure that your loan is paid throughout your qualification.
Changing your qualification

You can change your qualification and remain eligible for postgraduate funding providing you change to another eligible masters qualification. If you want to change your qualification you should seek advice and information from your student support team.

primary.introduction_text: When you apply for financial support for study-related costs, bursaries and scholarships, you'll need to provide us with evidence so that we can assess if you're eligible for an award.

rich_text_content.text: If you're applying for Financial Support for Access modules, you can find more detailed information about the evidence you need to provide in Evidence required for Financial Support for Access modules.
Depending on the funding you’re applying for, you may need to provide evidence of the benefit(s) you currently receive or declare either your personal or household income for the last full tax year.

note_body.text: Make sure you include your name and Personal Identifier (PI) on your evidence and only send copies of the evidence you submit, we don’t need to see the original document(s).

rich_text_content.text: Where possible, we advise you send this evidence electronically rather than by post. This is to ensure we can process your application as quickly as possible.  You can scan or photograph any supporting evidence and email it to the address on your application.
If you are unable to submit your evidence electronically, you can post it to the address on the application.
Income evidence

When you apply for means-tested funding based on your personal or household income, depending on which funding you're applying for, we'll ask you to declare and provide evidence of either your personal income or yours and your spouse/partner’s gross household income for the last complete tax year. You won’t need to declare your parents' income if they live in the same property.
The following information covers the different types of income you'll be asked to declare and the evidence you'll need to provide.
Gross income from paid employment or pension
P60 or P45
Pay slip from tax month 12 or tax week 53 showing ‘total paid to date’
Statement of earnings from your employer showing the total earnings for the last tax year.
Self-employment
Letter from a chartered or certified accountant confirming total income received in the last tax year
HMRC tax calculation
P60, P11D or confirmation of earnings from your chartered or certified accountant.
Income from retirement or disability pension
HMRC tax calculation
Pension company letter or statement confirming amount received during the last tax year
Letter from the Department for Work and Pensions or the Pension Service confirming amount received during the last tax year.
Interest from investments (for example, trusts, shares)
Letter or statement from bank, building society or investment company.
Income from benefits

If you (or your spouse or partner) receive a benefit, such as one listed below, which is paid as income for living costs, you'll need to declare it as income  and provide a copy of your award letter from Jobcentre Plus or a letter from the Department for Work and Pensions, confirming the amount and type of benefit you receive.
Other income

For any other income you (or your spouse or partner) receive which has not been covered above, you'll need to declare it under other income, this includes bursaries, maintenance payments or redundancy payments received.
Proof of other income including amount and date received.
Qualifying benefits evidence

If you tell us that you're applying for funding based on you (or your spouse or partner) being in receipt of one of the qualifying benefits listed below, you'll need to provide a copy of your or your spouse/partner’s most recent award letter from Jobcentre Plus. The letter must be dated within six months of the date you make your application.

If you're unable to send a copy of your or your spouse/partner’s award letter, or if you have an online account, we can accept a screengrab of the information displayed on your account. Make sure what your copy includes your name, address, type of benefit, the date you last received the benefit and the amount.
Qualifying benefits that this applies to are:
Income Support
Housing Benefit (including Local Housing Allowance)
Income-related Employment and Support Allowance (ESA)
Income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance (JSA)
Universal Credit
A reduction under the Council Tax Scheme (students in Wales only).

primary.introduction_text: If you’re starting an eligible part-time postgraduate masters degree (180 credits) or postgraduate diploma (120 credits) over two or three years, you may be eligible for a Postgraduate Tuition Fee Loan from Student Awards Agency Scotland (SAAS).

rich_text_content.text: The loan is up to a maximum of £7,000 towards your entire qualification, split pro rata over the number of years that you will be studying over. The loan is non-means tested and there is no upper age limit for applying.

The loan may not cover the full cost of your fees, so you may need to pay the difference using an alternative payment method. For information on other payment methods, see Postgraduate fees and funding.
Eligibility
You must:
be studying an eligible postgraduate course over a period of two or three years
be normally resident in Scotland and meet any other residency criteria set by SAAS
not have previously received public funding for a postgraduate qualification.
Postgraduate certificates (60 credits) are not eligible for the tuition fee loan.
How much you will receive
Your loan will be paid directly to the Open University (OU). The amount of loan you’ll receive each academic year is dependent on your qualification and its intended duration.
If you're studying over two academic years, then you'll be eligible for a Tuition Fee Loan of up to £3,500 each year.
If you're studying over three academic years, then you'll be eligible for a maximum Tuition Fee Loan of up to £2,333 each year (£2,334 in year three).
If you don’t use all your available loan in one year, it will not carry over to the next.
Repayments
You don't have to start repaying your loan until the April after you graduate or leave your qualification.

The Student Loan Company (SLC) is responsible for payments and repayments of the postgraduate tuition fee loan. SLC will expect you to pay nine per cent of your income each year once your salary exceeds the income threshold. The current threshold is £25,375. You will not have to pay your loan over a fixed period.
You can find out more at Student Awards Agency Scotland (SAAS).
How to apply
You should apply as soon as possible at Student Awards Agency Scotland (SAAS).

Take care to apply for the right number of years of loan support. Consider carefully the number of years you’ll be studying over, taking into account the structure of your qualification and which modules you would like to study each academic year. If you’re unsure about the length of your course, contact Student Fees (Scotland) by email at scotland@open.ac.uk.
It can take SAAS up to 28 days to process your application and they may contact you directly if they require any additional information.
Once your loan has been approved by SAAS, they’ll provide you with an award letter, available to download from your online SAAS account.
Complete your OU enrolment
Reserve a place on your chosen module, then sign and date your module registration agreement.
Send us a copy of your registration agreement, SAAS award letter and any additional payment (if required) by the final enrolment date of your first module.
You can send documents by email to scotland@open.ac.uk. Note: we cannot accept credit or debit card details via email.
You can also contact us if you require further support.

Be actively studying a minimum of 30 credits of Open University undergraduate or postgraduate study during the relevant academic year for which you're applying for a bursary.

primary.introduction_text: Postgraduate Loans are available from Student Finance England (SFE) for students starting an eligible masters qualification from 1 August 2016.

rich_text_content.text: The loan is non-means tested and is a contribution towards the costs of study and may not cover the full cost of an eligible masters qualification. Loans are available for masters degrees only and are not available for postgraduate certificates, postgraduate diplomas or masters apprenticeships programmes.
You must:
be studying a full masters degree of a minimum of 180 credits* – you won’t be eligible if you’re studying towards a postgraduate certificate or diploma
be ordinarily resident in England
be aged under 60 on the first day of the seasonal academic year in which your masters degree begins
be studying towards a masters degree that can be completed in no more than three years
not already hold a masters degree or higher qualification.

*If you're considering transferring previously completed credit to your OU masters degree, this could have an impact on your postgraduate loan eligibility. Contact Student Recruitment for further information.
The amount of loan and when you receive your loan is dependent on when you start your masters qualification.

rich_text_content.text: If you began a masters prior to 2021/22 but no earlier than 1 August 2016, you may be eligible to apply for a Postgraduate Loan; for further information, contact Student Recruitment.

The loan is paid directly to you in three instalments each year and you'll receive the first instalment after your qualification start date, not before. The loan is a contribution towards the cost of your postgraduate study and is not considered a Tuition Fee Loan. Therefore, in order to secure your module registration you’ll need to pay your module fees upfront yourself - for example, through an Open University Student Budget Account, by credit/debit card, or by mixed payments - by the specified final enrolment date for your module. The loan will then be paid to you after you start studying, subject to meeting the eligibility criteria.
If this is the second or third year of your Postgraduate Loan, you’ll receive your next payment after we can verify that you have started studying in that year.

heading.text: When will I receive my loan?

rich_text_content.text: You’ll receive your loan across either two or three years of your study. The total loan will be divided by the number of years you’re completing your studies in. Each year’s allocation will be paid in three instalments directly into your bank account.

Once your loan application is approved, your first module has started and you’re actively studying, we’ll confirm your registration to SFE and you’ll receive your first instalment direct into your bank account.

If we believe that you’ve stopped your studies i.e. by not submitting a Tutor Marked Assignment (TMA) or not logging into your course website, we’ll inform SFE who may stop the next instalment of your loan.

You should apply through SFE: Funding for postgraduate study. The loan application is straightforward; be sure to select part-time study as all OU masters qualifications are part-time. You’ll only need to apply for a loan once, but when you apply you should select the duration you’re planning to complete your qualification in – this will either be two or three years.
You'll also need to hand:
a valid UK Passport (if you have one)
your National Insurance number
your bank account details.

You can change your qualification and remain eligible for a Postgraduate Loan, providing you change to another eligible masters qualification. If you want to change your qualification, you should seek advice and information from your student support team (SST).

primary.introduction_text: As a student in Wales, you may be eligible to pay your tuition fees by taking out a student loan so you won’t have to pay your fees upfront. These is called a Part-time Tuition Fee loan and are is provided by Student Finance Wales (SFW).

rich_text_content.text: A Part-time Tuition Fee Loan is available even if you're planning to study 120 credits per year, which is equivalent to full-time intensity. Once you've told us you wish to pay by Part-time Tuition Fee Loan, you'll receive guidance from us on StudentHome on how to apply.

heading.text: Part-time Tuition Fee Loans in brief

rich_text_content.text: You need to reapply each year.
You can pay all or part of your fees with a fee loan of up to £2,625 in 2023/2024.
Part-time Tuition Fee loans are not means-tested.

You’ll apply for your Part-Time Tuition Fee loan directly from Student Finance Wales. We’ll guide you through the process but the final decision on your eligibility for a fee loan will be made by Student Finance Wales.
If you've already started your module you can apply up to nine months after the start of your seasonal academic year.
Repayments are based on what you earn, not what you owe, and are deducted automatically by your employer through the UK tax system.
You'll start to repay your Part-time Tuition Fee Loan from the April four years after you start your qualification or the April after you leave the course, whichever comes first.

If your income falls below the repayment threshold which applies to you, your repayments stop – for example, if you take a career break or are unemployed – until your earnings exceed the threshold again.

The loan repayment criteria relevant to you will be dependent on the terms and conditions in place for the academic year in which your loan started. Visit the Student Loans Company website for further details.
You'll need to:
be studying a module of at least 30 credits (25% intensity) each academic year
be studying towards an eligible undergraduate Open University (OU) qualification that is higher than any qualification you already hold (there are some exceptions to this*)
ensure you’re not behind in repayments, in arrears, or in overpayment with any previous financial support you've received from the Student Loans Company
meet the residency criteria which takes into consideration your nationality and residency status. For a list of the eligible categories, see Student Finance: Eligibility (SFW).

*If you're studying one of the following subjects, you may be eligible for a Part-time Tuition Fee loan even if you already have a degree: engineering, technology, computer science, nursing, biological sciences, psychology, physical sciences, mathematical sciences.
Visit Student Finance Wales (SFW) for more information.
If your loan application is declined or you want to change your payment method
You need to contact Student Recruitment as soon as possible. We can discuss alternative ways to pay and explain the next steps you need to take.

The easiest and quickest way to apply is by using the Student Finance Wales (SFW) online portal. Whether you're applying online or by paper application, it’s important you have the correct information to hand. SFW will need certain information regarding your course, including the course name, course start date and tuition fee amount. This needs to be provided to them in a certain format – once you've reserved a place on your module and told us you intend to pay using a Part-time Tuition Fee Loan, we'll give you all the information you need on 'Your student loan' page on StudentHome. Not using this information may result in your loan application being delayed and your tuition fees not being paid.
If you're unable to use the online application service, you can download a paper application and guidance notes or request a hard copy be sent by contacting SFW.
Most students can complete their entire application online. You’ll be able to agree to the Terms and Conditions via your SFW online account with an Electronic Signature.
SFW will send you a Student Finance Entitlement letter to confirm your Part-time Tuition Fee loan has been approved.
For detailed instructions on completing a successful application see guidance on completing your application.
If this is your first application

When you create an account with SFW using their online portal you'll be given a unique Customer Reference Number (CRN). Once you have completed and submitted your loan application you can use your CRN to complete your enrolment on your chosen modules.
If you apply using the paper application form, you'll be sent your CRN about 10 working days after submitting your application to SFW.
Your Part-time Tuition Fee Loan amount
You should apply for the maximum loan available so that if you decide to study additional modules in the same seasonal academic year you won't have to apply for a further loan.

SFW will only pay the OU the amount of loan required for the modules that you actually study. Any unused loan at the end of the year is disregarded and you'll only be liable for the actual loan instalments paid to us by SFW.
You can't carry over any unused loan and will need to make a new application for a loan each seasonal academic year.
If you decide to change your payment method or your module has already started

If you’ve paid for your module using another payment method and then decide you want to change your payment to a loan, you can apply for a Part-time Tuition Fee Loan up to nine months after the start of your relevant seasonal academic year.

If you’re applying after the module start date you should apply for your loan in the normal way (shown above) and contact Student Fees once your loan is approved. Once we've received confirmation from SFW that your loan has been approved we'll refund any fees paid up to the value of the loan.
If you've previously studied at another higher education institution

If you applied for a Tuition Fee Loan or a Fee or Course grant for a course at another higher education institution, you'll need to tell your previous university or college that you’re now studying with the OU. They’ll need to give permission to SFW for ownership of your student finance to be transferred to the OU. If you don't do this your loan application will be delayed. You only need to contact your previous university or college and not Student Finance Wales.
Help with your application
If you need information regarding your module fees to help you complete your loan application this can be found on 'Your student loan' page in StudentHome.
If you need help completing any other aspect of your application you should contact Student Finance Wales.

If you're having problems resolving any issues with SFW processing your application, we may be able to help. Contact Student Fees and we can discuss the best way to resolve the problem with you. You may need to set up a "consent to share" arrangement with SFW naming the OU as an organisation it can discuss your student record with.
For Welsh speakers
If you would prefer to discuss your study needs in Welsh, please email wales@open.ac.uk or call 029 2047 1170.
